I see what you're saying about the Junk DNA perhaps providing a specia=
l kind of randomness.  But one thing I find a little confusing is the idea =
that there is a special kind of random distribution that is better than oth=
er random distributions.  If that is true, then doesn't it require some inf=
ormation to encode what that distribution is?  And if it does need to be ch=
osen from some special distributions, and those distributions are captured =
by Junk DNA, which ends up being expressed, then why is it called "Junk DNA=
?"  Couldn't we essentially tell the same story in a simpler way by saying,=
 "a subset of DNA encodes the initial weight distribution in the brain?" Wh=
at then makes it junk?  And why use the word random either?

In any case, i=
t still does bring up whether a special activation function inspired by thi=
s idea might be helpful in establishing some aspect of initial connectivity=
.  I'm guessing that if that is true, then the advantage would probably sho=
w up more in plastic networks than static ones.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> On 6 March 2011 00:22, =
Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Colin,
> >
> > I think it's pretty rea=
sonable to speculate that some initial "primed" connectivity is
> > specifi=
ed through DNA that then goes through changes according to rules of plastic=
ity. Of
> > course, there is probably not a strict "pre-specified" period a=
nd another strict "plastic"
> > period, because in reality they likely over=
lap from the very start, but the general idea that
> > both elements are pr=
esent and that the pendulum swings gradually away from
> > pre-specificatio=
n makes sense to me.
> 
> Sure.
> 
> > From a neuroevolution perspective, i=
t's possible to
> > imagine variants of adaptive HyperNEAT that exhibit mor=
e or less of this type of dynamic.
> > Adaptive HyperNEAT was described in =
"Indirectly Encoding Neural Plasticity as a Pattern
> > of Local Rules," wh=
ich is at http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2010/risi.sab10.html . Of
> =
> course we are continuing to explore these types of plastic models.
> 
> >=
 About the junk DNA hypothesis - it's the type of thing you can't really de=
finitively verify as
> > true or false, but if some initial "randomness" in=
 the brain was provided by junk DNA it
> > wouldn't be that surprising. But=
 the thing I kind of object to in the quotations you provided
> > is the id=
ea that this idea is "bold." It doesn't seem to me to be a major problem to=
 explain
> > how disorganized randonmness can get into a system. I mean, ra=
ndom initialization (which
> > is a standard part of many EAs and other lea=
rning algorithms) is generally not the
> > interesting part, at least not i=
n terms of being the part that requires great intellectual effort
> > to co=
nceive or understand. So if nature in fact took one arbitrary route to gett=
ing a little
> > randomness into things over another, it doesn't seem that =
impressive or fortuitous
> > compared to how it discovered the parts that a=
re, in contrast, well-organized.
> 
> So I have a counterpoint to this argu=
ment that I'm not 100% sure how
> to explain but I'll have a go...
> 
> Yes=
 there are various ANN connection weight initialisation methods
> some of w=
hich employ randomness either by itself or as part of some
> broader method=
. Those techniques (AFAIK) tend to use traditional
> random number generato=
rs (RNGs) and either uniform or gaussian noise.
> I'm suggesting that if na=
ture had a use for this form of randomness
> then it would be fairly easy t=
o evolve from scratch and therefore
> wouldn't require utilisation of junk =
DNA. Easy to evolve because the
> noise could be said to have low Kolmogoro=
v complexity (can be
> generated by a simple algorithm), although I'm not 1=
00% sure how
> biologically plausible this part of my argument is.
> 
> So =
assuming for now that nature /is/ using junk DNA as a source of
> noise for=
 connection patterns *and* that there is an easier to
> discover source, th=
e question becomes - why use junk DNA?
> 
> This junk DNA has complexity an=
d structure that had utility in its
> origin domain, so as a source of conn=
ectivity patterns in this other
> unrelated domain it's /effectively/ rando=
m, but this is a form of
> randomness very much distinct from gaussian nois=
e, it has complex
> structure. E.g. consider using bytes from some random p=
ortion of
> computer RAM as a source of random numbers - it's going to have=
 very
> different properties than gaussian noise. Mathematically speaking t=
he
> junk DNA noise has a high(er) Kolmogorov complexity (it cannot be
> re=
presented by a simple/trivial algorithm as gaussian noise can be).
> So yes=
 it's arbitrary but it's also non-trivial to evolve from
> scratch, as such=
 it's possible that some properties of this complex
> random noise are usef=
ul for brains - e.g. maybe when mapped to
> connectivity patterns they have=
 a good proportion of short to long
> connection lengths (massively oversim=
plifying how complex this junk
> DNA might be here, but maybe that helps ex=
plain my argument).
> 
> [As a side note all of this sort of fits in with y=
our talk on
> serendipity and novelty search]
> 
> [As another side note I =
would also add that if junk DNA is being used
> it's likely that it's being=
 used for things other than connectivity
> patterns - that's just one hypot=
hesis. We know that this DNA is being
> expressed but don't know for sure i=
f it has an utility, it might just
> be a side effect of other useful DNA b=
eing expressed (holding on for
> the ride)]
> 
> But if you take on the ass=
umptions I've stated then this has
> implications for CPPNs. Currently our =
CPPNs are mostly using
> continuous functions operating on a continuous coo=
rdinate space - and
> therefore generate continuous/smooth connectivity pat=
terns. Should we
> consider inclusing a means of introducing complexity int=
o the patterns
> early on that isn't directly evolved? e.g. some new CPPN f=
unction that
> refers to a chunk of complex random noise? For a laugh we co=
uld use
> actual junk DNA sequences from nature translated into numbers -
>=
 probably as good a source as any :)
> 
> Colin.
>
